title: UN Security Council Condemns North Korea's Latest ICBM Test
introText: The United Nations Security Council has unanimously condemned North Korea's latest intercontinental ballistic missile test, which demonstrated enhanced range and payload capabilities. The launch has prompted renewed calls for diplomatic engagement and strengthened sanctions.

content.content: UN Security Council addresses North Korean missile program

North Korea's Hwasong-19 missile flew over 1,000 kilometers and reached an altitude of 6,500 kilometers before landing in the Sea of Japan. Experts estimate the missile could reach anywhere in the continental United States if fired on a standard trajectory.

The test demonstrated improved solid-fuel technology, allowing faster launch preparation and reduced vulnerability to preemptive strikes. North Korea claimed successful testing of multiple reentry vehicles.

In a rare unanimous statement, all 15 Security Council members condemned the launch as a 'flagrant violation' of multiple UN resolutions. The council called on Pyongyang to return to denuclearization talks immediately.
New sanctions targeting North Korea's weapons procurement networks were proposed, though Russia and China expressed reservations about their effectiveness.
South Korea and Japan convened emergency security meetings following the launch. Both countries announced enhanced missile defense cooperation and joint exercises with US forces.
The US Indo-Pacific Command confirmed heightened readiness across regional bases. President reaffirmed 'ironclad' commitment to defending allies.
Despite condemnation, some diplomats see the test as a prelude to negotiations. North Korea has historically used provocations to strengthen its bargaining position before diplomatic engagement.
